\title{Daniel Lemire, Ph.D.}

\maketitle

%\textbf{Vision statement}: insure that technology continues to make individuals and communities smarter.
\textbf{Keywords}: Database Theory, Data Warehousing, Multidimensional
Databases (OLAP), Data Mining, Time Series, Collaborative Filtering, Information Retrieval.



\section{Experience}

\begin{topic}
\item [2004-...] Computer Science Professor, Téluq\\
(Full professor since 2009)\\
\textbf{Université du Québec à Montréal (UQAM)}\\
\url{http://www.professeurs.uqam.ca/pages/lemire.daniel.htm}

\item [2002-2004] Research Officer in eBusiness\\
Institute for Information Technology, E-business\\
\textbf{National Research Council of Canada (NRC)}

\item [2002-2003] Team Leader for the e-Health Research Group\\
Institute for Information Technology \\
\textbf{National Research Council of Canada (NRC)}

\item [2001-2002] Assistant Professor\\
\textbf{Acadia University}

\item [1999-2001] Independent Scientific Consultant\\
\textbf{TechElements Inc.} and \textbf{Ondelette.com}

\item [1998-1999] Post-doctoral fellow\\
\textbf{Institut de génie biomédial}

\end{topic}
\section{Education}

\textbf{École Polytechnique de Montréal}\\
Supervisors: Gilles Deslauriers and Serge Dubuc

\item [1994-1995] M.Sc. {}``A Priori Approximations for Nonlinear Systems''\\
\textbf{University of Toronto}\\
Supervisor: Catherine Sulem

\item [1990-1994] B.Sc. in Mathematics with ``High Distinction''\\
\textbf{University of Toronto}
\end{topic}

\section{Supervision}
% 
% During the summer of 2003, Sean McGrath, a student from the University
% of New Brunswick, joined us to work on the Lemur Project. The Lemur
% Project is software written in C++ and Python for fast computations
% over data cubes. I then co-supervised Sean with
% Harold Boley on the project ``RACOFI Composer'', and then I 
% provided NSERC funding to Sean so he could work with us a third term.
% One result of this work was the site inDiscover (http://www.indiscover.net). 
% 
% During the Winter 2003 term, I supervised Nancy Howse from Acadia
% University as a CO-OP student in the context of Scale and Translation
% Invariant Collaborative Filtering Systems. The project was called
% COFI Music and it was a subproject of the \textit{Sifter} project with Mosaic
% Corporation. Following the success of the first term, Nancy returned
% for a second term during the summer of 2003. The result of her work
% is a servlet-based web site (racofi.elg.ca) showing how the theory can
% be applied.
%  
%  %As of February 2005, Nancy Howse works for Blue Cross in Halifax.
% 
% Moreover, in 2002-2003, with Harold Boley, I co-supervised Marcel Ball (2 COOP terms), Stephen Greene (1 COOP term) and Michelle Anderson (1 COOP term).

I coauthored several of my talks, articles and reports with the students I supervised~\cite{elearningsummit, COLA2003, elearningsummitpaper, TRD01, BELL2004-TR,TRD05001,apics2005}.

\section{Research program}
\begin{itemize}
\item OLAP and Very Large Databases: fast queries and updates
by wavelets and efficient storage through hybrid OLAP~\cite{CASCON2002,IS2006,DOLAP2003}. Lately, I have been
especially interested in the application of OLAP techniques to text mining~\cite{apics2005}. This work is done
in close collaboration with Owen Kaser (UNB/SJ).
\item eBusiness Data Mining and Collaborative Filtering~\cite{elearningsummitpaper,SIGIR2003,slopeone,COLA2003}: some of the results of my work were licensed in October 2004 by Bell Canada and are now core
to the Bell Sympatico/MSN Web site inDiscover.
  Collaborators include
Stephen Downes~(NRC~Moncton), Anna Maclachlan~(Idilia Inc.), Bruce Spencer~(NRC~Fredericton), and Harold Boley~(NRC~Fredericton). %RACOFI
%Composer is part of the RuleML initiative from DFKI. 
\item Time Series Mining and especially Isotonic Segmentation of Time Series~\cite{ICDM-05,reactivecontrol,IJCAI05,ylbMBR2004,ylbMonet2004}. This work is
done with Yuhong Yan~(NRC~Fredericton), Martin Brooks~(NRC~Ottawa), Will Fitzgerald (NASA Ames),  and Dan Kucerovsky~(UNB).
\end{itemize}

\subsection{Research funding (excluding NRC)}
\begin{itemize}
\item FQRNT Grant (Quebec Government) in 2006-2008 (\$54,249) as a new researcher.
\item NSERC Grant 2003-2007 (OLAP and Collaborative Filtering), committee 330, \$12,000 a year ou \$48,000: attributed as an adjunct professor at UNB.
\item Institutional Grant (FIR) in 2004-2005 (\$2,500).
\item Institutional Grant (FIR) in 2005-2006 (\$2,300).
\item Institutional Grant (FIR) in 2005-2006 (\$1,200).
\end{itemize}


\subsection{Research Prizes}
\begin{itemize}
\item I won the Best Paper Award at CASCON 2002 in Toronto. The organizing
committee of the IBM-sponsored conference has recognized the excellence
of my work on database acceleration by wavelets.
\end{itemize}

\section{Services (external)}

\subsection{Organizing Committees}
\begin{itemize}
\item I was co-chair of the Emerging Technologies for Web-based Communities (ET-WBC) Workshop (Mondragon University, Spain, February 25th 2006) with Mamadou Tadiou.
\item I was co-chair of the ``Canadian Semantic Web Symposium 2006 (CSWWS'06)''  with Mamadou Tadiou. The proceedings are published by Springer. The event received financial support from the Rule Markup Initiative, Ontotext,  UQAM, and Laval University.
\item In November 2004, I was in the SWIG'04 organizing committee with Griff Richards, Bruce Spencer, Harold Boley, Fred Popowich, and Olga Marino.
\end{itemize}

\subsection{Thesis Review}
\begin{itemize}
\item During the winter 2004, I was a
reviewer for a Ph.D. thesis by Sreeraman Rajan  
supervised by professors 
Doraiswami and Stevenson,
in Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of New Brunswick.
The thesis is on wavelet-based classification of phonocardiograms.
The title is:``A Wavelet-based Correlator Approach for Segmentation
and Classification of the First Two Heart Sounds in a PCG Signal.''
\item In September 2003, I was the external reviewer for Fang Wang's Computer Science M.Sc. thesis
at the University of New Brunswick. She wrote her thesis under the supervision
of Bruce Spencer and Ali Ghorbani. The title of her thesis was ``Detecting and
Preventing Rule Conflicts in APPEL.''
\end{itemize}

\item I host the Data Warehouse and OLAP bibliography
which was previously

350~hits per day: \url{http://www.daniel-lemire.com/OLAP}.
\item I run my own blog at \url{http://www.daniel-lemire.com/blog/}. It receives about 250~hits per day.
\end{itemize}



\section{Media}

\begin{itemize}
\item In  the winter of 2001, I was invited to the TV show {}``C'est mathématiques!'' ({}``It's
mathematics!'') on {}``Canal Z'' to discuss Canadian
innovations in geophysical data processing. {}``Canal Z'' is the
major French TV channel in Canada featuring technology and science
programs. {}``C'est mathématiques!'' has been on the air for several
years.
\item I gave an interview for the {}``Bulletin de l'AMQ'' (Bulletin of
the {}``Quebec Mathematical Society'') on the theme {}``consulting
in the industry as a mathematician'' (Autumn 2001). The {}``AMQ''
is the only major Mathematical Society in Quebec and has thousands
of members who all receive the {}``Bulletin de l'AMQ.''
\end{itemize}

\section{Industry and Consulting}
\begin{itemize}
\item Since May 2006, I'm a scientific consultant for Intalgent (Virginia, USA).
\item My ``Slope One'' Collaborative Filtering algorithm is used by the DVD
recommender site \url{http://hitflip.de} and by the content management engine Drupal. It is implemented in the Vogoo (\url{http://www.vogoo-api.com}) and Taste (\url{http://taste.sourceforge.net/}) software libraries. 
\item In October 2004, in a three-way agreement between Daniel Lemire, NRC, and Bell Canada, Bell
Canada licensed the technology behind the \url{http://inDiscover.net} Web site.
The Web site became a Bell Sympatico/MSN web site on November 5$^{\textrm{th}}$ 2004. The term ``indiscover'' is found in over 18~900 Web pages  according to Google.
NRC promotes the technology on its site\footnote{\url{http://iit-iti.nrc-cnrc.gc.ca/projects-projets/racofi-composer_e.html}} stating that:
\begin{quote}The performance of Slope-One is remarkable; recommendations can be culled from collection of a million rated songs in a matter of seconds.
\end{quote}
\item I was the consulting scientist for the first wavelet-based image server
at the {}``Serveur national de radiologie'' in France ({}``National
Radiology Server'') \cite{key-42,key-44}. Serving medical images
(DICOM) on the Web is a major undertaking since the average radiologist
will generate over 4~gigabytes of raw data per day. The result of this work is known as the {}``Waaves''
format and it is now in use in France for storing and retrieving
digital radiology images and thousands of images are sent every day
using this system. \textbf{This product was nominated for an IST prize.}
\item Over several years, I worked with THEM Geophysics Inc. with funding
from FalconBridge and CAMIRO (Canadian Mining Industry Research Organization)
on improving geophysical data processing for the THEM system. The
THEM system is the only Canadian airborne EM system for exploring
rough terrains. The signal-to-noise ratio was improved by at least
100\% using better mathematical modeling namely by multiscale methods.
The software has been used successfully in Northern Canada and Sudan
in exploration contracts worth several millions of dollars. I gave
a 5 minutes interview on television concerning this project.
\item I was a scientific advisor for MathSoft Inc. in the design of
the following Mathcad extension packs: signal processing, image processing,
and wavelet. Mathcad is one of the most important mathematical software
on the market.
\end{itemize}

\section{Software}
\begin{itemize}
 \item Daniel Lemire and Raj Bhaskar, \textit{WebForum}, hosted on Sourceforge, released under GPL, 1999. WebForum was downloaded nearly 4000 times since 1999. Currently,
 there are about 4 downloads and 50 visitors to the site daily.
\item Daniel Lemire, \textit{Cofi: A Java-Based Collaborative Filtering Library}, hosted on Savannah, released under GPL, November 2003.
 \item Daniel Lemire and Owen Kaser, \textit{Lemur OLAP Library}, hosted on Savannah, released under GPL, November 2003.
 \item Daniel Lemire (maintainer), Tim Hochberg \textit{et al.}, \textit{JNumeric: Numerical Python for Jython}, hosted by Sourceforge, released under the Python license, 2002. It has been
 downloaded nearly 1000 times since 2002.
\item At the end of the 1990, I contributed several classes, including a wavelet package, to the JSci (Objects for Science) library.  In 2001,  John Carr wrote a paper in  IBM DeveloperWorks called ``JSci: An open-source alternative for Java 2D graphing''~\footnote{\url{http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/java/library/j-2dgraphics/}} describing the usage of the Swing classes I created.
 \item I also contributed to other projects
including jnews (RSS aggregator in Python),
and  gnu.trove.
\end{itemize}
